The Board of Trustees approved the appointment of Dr. Benisha Carr to the position of Alternative Education Principal. Dr. Carr comes to Beaumont USD from Victor Valley Union High School District where she has served since 2006. She has held the positions of middle school teacher, middle school dean of students, summer school coordinator, and most recently high school assistant principal in the Alternative Education Program.

Dr. Carr earned her Bachelor of Arts from the University of California Irvine, a Master of Education from the University of La Verne, a Master of Arts in Educational Leadership from Azusa Pacific University, and her Doctor of Education in Organizational Leadership from the University of La Verne.

Please join us in welcoming Dr. Benisha Carr to her new position of Principal for Glen View High School and 21st Century Learning Institute.

On Tuesday, February 27, the Beaumont Unified School District Administration was notified about an alleged threat on social media referencing 'BHS' and immediately contacted the Beaumont Police Department.

Law enforcement started an investigation and determined the posting has been circulating social media for the past several days. The threat was made to a high school located in Belen, New Mexico. The student involved in that incident was arrested by authorities.

The District’s number one priority is the safety and well-being of our students and we take any kind of threat seriously. Beaumont Police will have a presence at our schools today.

This is a reminder for all parents to monitor their children’s social media and have a conversation about the seriousness of posting any kind of reference to violence or threats to schools. We encourage the entire school community to immediately report anything suspicious to law enforcement and not spread rumors via social media.

Information can also be provided anonymously by on the police department’s website at beaumontpd.org or crimetips@beaumontpd.org.

September 21, 2015 at 12:27 PM ·

The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) will conduct a Family-to-Family Education program starting Sept. 29 in Beaumont.
The 12-week course is for family members and significant others of persons with mental illness.
Clinical treatments will be discussed and knowledge and skills will be provided for how family members can cope more effectively with the illness.
Topics will include schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, panic disorder, borderline personality disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, along with others.
Registration is required but there is no charge for the course. Class size is limited.
The class will be held at Beaumont Presbyterian Church, 702 Euclid Ave. in Beaumont.
For information, call Kathy Faber at (951) 797-0120 or Ruth Meza at (951) 961-8563.
